transcript: [Visual: Speaker states that typical career advice revolves around discovering one's passion.] [Visual: A man with glasses speaks in front of a black background with text at the bottom and a graphic above his head.] [Visual: Speaker poses the question of what motivates the audience.] : Typical career advice tends to be discover your passion. [Visual: Speaker emphasizes that discovering passion is important.] : What motivates you? [Visual: Speaker encourages the audience to pursue their passion.] : And by the way, that's important. [Visual: Speaker explains that if you hate something, you likely won't be good at it.] : Of course, you should. [Visual: Speaker asserts that if you hate your work, you will be miserable.] : Because if I hate that, then probably not gonna be good at it. [Visual: Speaker says that passion is important, but from a business perspective, it is important to think about the product and services.] : You're certainly gonna be miserable, right? [Visual: Speaker asks what your product and services are.] : So passion is important, but like when you think about it from a business perspective and entrepreneurship perspective, it's like, well, what are your product and services? : What are your-
description: How a successful entrepreneur should think

transcript: [Visual: Kerry Washington discusses AI and creativity, the excitement and intrigue surrounding AI, and the inevitability of its progress, emphasizing the need to protect humanity.] [Visual: Kerry Washington is centered on a colorful background, discussing AI and creativity.] : AI-powered tools excite you, terrify you, intrigue you? [Visual: A man with glasses speaks about how AI excites him, accompanied by an animation of AI-related items.] : Anybody who wants to put it back in the bottle, like, I'm so sorry. [Visual: A gloved hand is moving a blue bottle with an AI label on it in front of a grid background.] : That's just not happening. [Visual: Kerry Washington is speaking in a bright, indoor setting.] : So I think the biggest issues are around protecting the humanity that is utilized to foster the creativity. [Visual: Kerry Washington highlights the crucial aspects of consent and compensation in AI usage, focusing on how to track consent and fairly compensate talent.] : So for me, it's really about both consent and compensation, and the key is gonna be to figure out how we are able to track consent. [Visual: Kerry Washington is speaking in a bright setting.] [Visual: A gloved hand is holding a magnifying glass over a document with the word 'Consent' written on it.] : How do we figure out what is authenticated, uh, from the talent and what isn't? : And then how do we compensate accordingly? [Visual: Kerry Washington emphasizes the importance of treating people like human beings in the context of AI.] [Visual: A woman is speaking directly to the camera, with a neutral background visible behind her.]
hashtags: reidhoffman, kerrywashington, innovation, ai, Tech, tech

transcript: [Visual: Speaker begins by questioning the unique set of puzzle pieces entrepreneurs assemble to change the world.] [Visual: A man with glasses is talking while a puzzle with an image of a ship and an air balloon is being assembled.] [Visual: Speaker explains that entrepreneurship allows for unique paths.] : What's the unique set of puzzle pieces that you're putting together to make the Archimedean lever by which you change the world? [Visual: Speaker mentions that sometimes the path involves being a disruptor in your field.] : One of the awesome things about entrepreneurship is that each path can be very unique. [Visual: Speaker points out that the path can be unique.] [Visual: The road in the field is now a winding road with the word 'ENTREPRENEURSHIP' above it.] [Visual: Speaker highlights that finding your own path, such as partnering with corporations, is part of entrepreneurship.] : Sometimes that path is just kinda grow in your own field, be the disruptor. [Visual: The road in the field now has road markings.] : Sometimes, actually, in fact, it's a unique path. : It's partnering with a corporation the right way, it's taking something that says, "Well, most people don't do it this way, but because of what we're doing, because of the mission of what we're doing in the world, this is the ensuing strategy." And so part of entrepreneurship is find your own path.
description: The power of uniqueness in entrepreneurship
hashtags: reidhoffman, StartUp, entrepreneur, business, innovation, startup

transcript: [Visual: The speaker believes that there will be better tools to navigate future risks.] : And part of what we have is, I think we're going to have better tools even to navigate the risk in our future. [Visual: The speaker acknowledges that some people are concerned about the risks but are also working to address them.] : So it's part of the reason why people say, "Well, on one hand, you've got these people talking about the risk. [Visual: The speaker emphasizes the importance of taking an approach that focuses on navigating future risks.] : On the other hand, they're really working to build it." It's like, yes, things in the future, and there's better ways of navigating the risks, and I think that's exactly the kind of approach we should be taking.
description: Challenges posed by regulations to AI innovation

transcript: [Visual: Speaker states that the world has changed and the importance of entrepreneurial skills has increased.] [Visual: A close-up shot of a man in glasses talking, with a smaller inset of another man on a phone call and an earth globe.] [Visual: Speaker believes that while not everyone should be an entrepreneur, everyone should be entrepreneurial.] : The world has changed. [Visual: Speaker emphasizes the increasing importance of entrepreneurial skills due to the pandemic and industry changes.] : Not that we should all be entrepreneurs, some of us should be entrepreneurs, but we should all be entrepreneurial. [Visual: Speaker highlights that applying entrepreneurial skills is beneficial even for those seeking traditional jobs and careers.] : And the skills of being entrepreneurial are important, by the way, more important now even than before because of pandemic and change in industries and all these things. : But we should bring the skillset of an entrepreneur to your own life even if what you're doing is just, you know, getting jobs and working in interesting companies and doing the thing that's great for you.
description: How can you transform rejection into growth?

transcript: [Visual: A man introduces the topic by discussing AI tools like ChatGPT, GPT-4, Bing, and Bard, and questions the current state of AI as a universal tool that has disrupted work and education.] [Visual: A man smiles in front of a blue background with the words 'BUILDING THE RIGHT TOOLS FOR AN AI FUTURE' above him and a graphic of an AI chip to his right.] : ChatGPT, GPT-4. : Bing, Bard. : What do you think of the current state of the art? [Visual: Logos for 'G Bard', GPT-4, and Bing are displayed on a yellow and brown striped background with the text 'WHAT DO YOU THINK OF THE'.] : This is a universal tool. : It's available to everybody, and there's so much debate over what happens next. [Visual: Three people look at their phones and smile, with an illustration in the background that shows a man in a suit at a podium.] : How much smarter will this get? : But we've already completely disrupted work and education, but the tools aren't really supporting work and education use. [Visual: The video highlights the need for better AI tools and shows how users have to "hack" AI to produce essays or do good work, emphasizing the importance of improving the learning interface.] : You kind of have to work around it. : You kind of have to hack a chatbot to produce an essay for you or do good work for you. [Visual: The silhouette of a person is shown working on a computer, with text above reading 'OR DO GOOD WORK FOR YOU'.] : And I think that some of this is really about that learning interface.
description: Building the right tools for an AI future
